Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Role Of Fortifications In Long Term Political Process

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Ian Lindsay (Purdue University) and collaborators Dr. Alan Greene (Stanford University), Dr. Maureen Marshall (University of Illinois-Urbana Champaign), Dr. Lori Khatchadourian (Cornell University) and Dr. Adam T. Smith (Cornell University), along with collaborators in Armenia, will investigate the relationship between warfare, settlement patterns, and political development in the ancient past. Traditional social science scholarship on pre-modern warfare has typically framed conflict as a rational pursuit of material needs, or as a strategic contest among aspiring elites seeking political advantage in the evolution toward political complexity. However, archaeology is well-positioned to offer a more nuanced perspective of ancient warfare that focuses on the broader fields of social action and historical contexts that shape the motivations, goals, and cultural practices of war. This research will contribute essential time depth to the study of contemporary regional conflicts, their impacts on the politics and identities of social groups, and the ties to place and polity. As persistent ethnic and civil clashes continue to impact contemporary life, understanding the impact of war in the past can help frame the causes and implications of modern conflicts while shaping responses to them. This research will contribute to actionable scholarly efforts to understand the long-term impacts on human political, economic, and settlement practices and subjectivities that emerge within fortified and militarized landscapes.

The ubiquity of stone hillforts in the South Caucasus and the prevalence of metal weapons indicate that violence played an essential role in regional sociopolitical development. Dr. Lindsay and his co-investigators will study the institutional mechanisms through which warfare constituted authority, created and dissolved political association, and shaped a specific form of political economy during the Late Bronze Age and Iron Age periods (ca. 1500-200 BC). The researchers will examine the role of violence and warfare in community formation, social order, and sociopolitical boundaries through a diachronic study of fortified landscapes in the upper Kasakh River valley of northwestern Armenia. In particular, they will address questions regarding how the history of fortress construction and abandonment inform models of political association, what types of violent practices in these areas are evidenced in burial goods and inscribed on human skeletal remains, and how patterns of politics and warfare in the Caucasus correlate with regional environmental shifts and historical change in the neighboring Near East and Eurasian Steppe. The research team will employ a battery of traditional and cutting-edge archaeological approaches to address these issues, including pedestrian and magnetometry survey; the use of drones for aerial photogrammetry of fortresses and associated settlements; test excavation of burials and forts; pollen analysis of a bog core to reconstruct paleoenvironmental contexts; analysis of human remains to study demography, trauma, diet, mobility, and social identity; and portable X-ray fluorescence (pXRF) and digital radiography on pottery materials to illuminate preliminary patterns of goods circulation. Combined, these techniques will provide the groundwork for a robust evaluation of the long-term engagement of warfare and sociopolitical life in the South Caucasus. In addition, this research will facilitate the training of a new generation of archaeologists in a range of advanced research methods, which will help improve the research infrastructure of scholarship in a region that remains economically disadvantaged.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Three seasons of NSF-funded research by Kasakh Valley Archaeological Survey (KVAS) have yielded promising, if preliminary, results from sites spanning the Paleolithic through the Bronze Age, and reinforced the strong archaeological research potential of the upper Kasakh Valley of northern Armenia to answer questions related to ancient land-use, sociopolitical development, and human-environment interaction. Research activities included two seasons of pedestrian site survey, excavations of Bronze Age burials, test excavations at two fortresses, extraction and ongoing analysis of a bog core to reconstruct ancient climate regimes, and UAV-based aerial mapping.

The KVAS survey recovered a substantial record of the earliest peopling of the Kasakh Valley, identifying nearly two dozen sites spanning the Paleolithic, including Upper and Middle Paleolithic obsidian tools associated with Homo erectus and Neanderthals, respectively. The presence of open-air Paleolithic finds reinforces the notion that northern Armenia exhibits high potential for addressing questions related to the dispersal of early human populations in the Caucasus and their adaptations to highland environments. 

Our survey also documented some of the region’s earliest agro-pastoralist occupations in the Kasakh Valley, represented by mid-to-late 4th millennium settlements attributed to the “Kura-Araxes” cultural phenomenon, focused along the main trunk of the Kasakh River and its tributaries. Significant to our finds is evidence in the distribution of settlements for discrete communities, or land tenure groups, within these sub-valleys, which, when tested through excavation and circulation studies, will provide a more refined understanding of how Kura-Araxes communities interacted with each other at different geographic scales—an underexplored issue related to how Kura-Araxes material culture spread from the South Caucasus across Anatolia to the eastern Mediterranean. Traditionally, Kura-Araxes research has been conducted at either of two scales: on the broad regional canvas of the Armenian Highland and Anatolia, or on the highly localized site scale. Our results demonstrate that further systematic survey in the South Caucasus can help bridge these perspectives and lend much needed insight into Kura-Araxes interactions at the intermediate, landscape scale. 

When intensive occupation returned to the Kasakh Valley in the late 2nd millennium BC, it came not in the form of valley bottom settlements but through the proliferation of hilltop fortresses, which marks the onset of the Late Bronze Age (1500-1100 BC). Together with a dramatic increase in the quantity and diversity of weapons, these fortifications suggest that violence gained singular prominence as a factor of sociopolitical life—a view supported by excavated skeletal remains that exhibit a high rate of trauma. While the exact dynamics of Late Bronze political processes and causes of social conflict remain open archaeological questions, it is clear that fortresses are dispersed across the highlands and often located only a few kilometers from each other in what may have been loose and fragile networks of affiliation. This certainly seems evident in the Kasakh Valley, where fortresses at Mirak, Aver Berd, Aparani Berd and Dzoraglukh demonstrate both the density and spatial distribution of settlement. Ongoing climatic reconstructions through the analysis of bog cores will help us better understand the environmental contexts of these dramatic changes to the archaeological landscape.

Critical to our ability to record fine-grained survey data in the field was our mobile GIS data collection system and drone-based photogrammetric mapping methods, which we developed to make the process of documenting sites not only more efficient but also more analytically productive. For data collection on transect, we relied on a paperless, digital platform based on ESRI’s Collector for ArcGIS app loaded onto iPads. Recorded data were then updated instantaneously across each survey member’s tablet via cellular connection, a process that both enhances information flow across survey transects and improves data entry quality control. The survey entries are then synced from the project GIS server to the Project ArAGATS database to ensure long term curation and security. Overall, we found that the combination of paperless data collection, aerial survey, and remote data porting and post-processing provided a powerful and efficient approach to settlement survey, and enhanced our productivity by expanding our capacity to compare and interpret multiple survey datasets in a regional context.
